The self-assessment component is as important as the essay itself because it develops metacognition — the ability to evaluate one's own work. Review the essay and self-assessment together. Celebrate strengths and discuss goals constructively. If your child identified 'using more evidence' as a goal, help them practice finding and citing evidence in everyday conversations.

title: Geometry Assessment — Applying Angle and Shape Properties
description: Students consolidate their geometry learning by solving problems that combine angle measurement, triangle classification, the Triangle Inequality Theorem, quadrilateral properties, and area formulas. They demonstrate mastery through a variety of problem types.
instructions:
1. Review angle types and measurement.
2. Review complementary and supplementary angles.
3. Review triangle classification by sides and angles.
4. Review the Triangle Inequality Theorem.
5. Review quadrilateral properties and angle sums.
6. Review the triangle area formula.
7. Students complete a comprehensive geometry assessment.
8. Include measurement, classification, calculation, and reasoning problems.
9. Self-check and error analysis.
10. Set goals for geometry concepts that need more practice.

slides.heading: Geometry Review
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our big geometry adventure this week. It's telling us we're going to be reviewing everything about shapes, especially angles and different kinds of triangles and four-sided figures called quadrilaterals. Think of it as the main topic we're going to explore.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare comprehensive review worksheets covering all week's geometry topics. Provide formula reference cards and protractors. Include problems of varying difficulty.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is showing us all the tools we'll need for our geometry work. We've got protractors for measuring angles, rulers for drawing straight lines and measuring lengths, and a worksheet with practice problems. We'll also use a formula card to help us remember important math rules, graph paper for drawing, and calculators if we need them, along with our pencils to write everything down.

slides.text: This week in geometry: Angles — measuring, classifying (acute, right, obtuse, straight, reflex), complementary pairs (sum to 90), supplementary pairs (sum to 180). Triangles — classified by sides (equilateral, isosceles, scalene) and angles (acute, right, obtuse). Triangle Inequality: any two sides must sum to more than the third.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about angles and triangles. We'll learn how to measure angles using a protractor and give them names like acute (small and pointy), right (like a square corner), or obtuse (wide open). We'll also see how angles can be pairs that add up to 90 degrees (complementary) or 180 degrees (supplementary), and how triangles can be named based on their sides or their angles.

slides.text: Quadrilaterals — angle sum is always 360 degrees. Properties: rectangles (all 90-degree angles), parallelograms (opposite angles equal, consecutive angles supplementary), rhombuses (all sides equal), trapezoids (one pair of parallel sides). Knowing properties lets you solve for unknown angles.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're diving into four-sided shapes, called quadrilaterals, and remembering that all their angles always add up to 360 degrees. We'll look at special ones like rectangles, parallelograms, rhombuses, and trapezoids, and learn their unique rules, like which angles are equal or parallel. Knowing these properties will help us figure out missing angles in these shapes.

slides.text: Triangle area: A = 1/2 x base x height. Height must be perpendicular to the base. Works for all triangles. Can solve for missing dimensions: if Area = 40 and base = 10, then height = Area x 2 / base = 8. Compound shapes: break into rectangles and triangles, find each area, add together.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part focuses on the area of triangles, which is basically how much space they cover. The formula is "one half times the base times the height," but it's super important that the height line is perfectly straight up and down from the base. We'll also practice finding missing information if we know the area, and even figure out the area of shapes made by combining triangles and rectangles, just like building with blocks.

slides.text: Problem-solving strategy: (1) Read carefully and identify what is given and what is asked. (2) Draw a diagram if one is not provided. (3) Identify which properties or formulas apply. (4) Solve step by step, showing your work. (5) Check your answer: Does it make sense? Is the angle measure reasonable? Is the area positive?
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide gives us a game plan for tackling any geometry problem. First, we need to read carefully to see what information we have and what we need to find. If there's no picture, we should draw one to help us see things better. Then, we pick the right math rules or formulas, solve it step-by-step, and finally, we check if our answer makes sense, like if an angle is super big or small when it shouldn't be.

slides.prompt: Geometry assessment: (1) Measure and classify 5 angles. (2) Find the complement of 34 degrees and the supplement of 127 degrees. (3) Classify 4 triangles by sides and angles. (4) Can these lengths form triangles? (3,5,7), (2,2,5), (6,6,6), (4,7,12). (5) A parallelogram has one angle of 58 degrees. Find all four angles. (6) Find the area of triangles with: base 14 cm / height 9 cm; base 7.5 m / height 4 m. (7) A triangle has an area of 48 square cm and a base of 16 cm. Find the height. (8) Find the total area of a house-shaped figure: a 10 m x 6 m rectangle topped with a triangle (base 10 m, height 4 m).
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to put everything we've learned to the test with this assessment! You'll measure and name some angles, figure out missing angles, and classify different triangles. You'll also use the Triangle Inequality rule to see if shapes can actually be made, solve for unknown angles in parallelograms, and calculate the areas of triangles and a cool house shape. You've got 25 minutes, so focus and show off what you know!

slides.text: Geometry connects the abstract world of mathematics to the physical world around us. Every building, bridge, and work of art uses the properties of angles, triangles, and quadrilaterals. The skills you developed this week — measuring, classifying, proving, and calculating — are the foundation of all advanced geometry.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student accurately measure and classify angles, classify triangles by sides and angles, apply the Triangle Inequality Theorem, solve for unknown angles in quadrilaterals, and calculate triangle areas?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide reminds us why geometry is so awesome – it's all around us! From the buildings we live in to the art we see, shapes and angles are the building blocks. You've just practiced measuring, naming, solving, and calculating, which are super important skills that help you understand the world and will be useful for even more math later on.

parent_notes: Review day is about consolidation, not new learning. If your child struggles with specific concepts, focus practice on those areas. Common challenges: reading the protractor wrong scale (estimate first to check), identifying height in obtuse triangles (the height can fall outside the triangle), and remembering which properties belong to which quadrilateral. Hands-on practice with real objects helps: measure angles in furniture, identify triangle types in architecture, calculate areas of garden spaces.

title: The Renaissance Spreads — From Italy to Northern Europe
description: Students trace the spread of Renaissance ideas from Italy to Northern Europe, examining how the printing press, trade, and cultural exchange carried new ideas across the continent. They compare Italian and Northern Renaissance art and thinkers.
instructions:
1. Review the Italian Renaissance: origins, artists, ideas.
2. Discuss how ideas spread: trade routes, diplomacy, the printing press.
3. Introduce the Northern Renaissance: Netherlands, Germany, England, France.
4. Compare Italian vs. Northern Renaissance art: idealized vs. realistic.
5. Introduce Albrecht Durer: the 'Leonardo of the North.'
6. Introduce Jan van Eyck and the development of oil painting.
7. Discuss Erasmus and Northern humanist philosophy.
8. Examine the printing press's role: Gutenberg's revolution.
9. Students create a map tracing the spread of Renaissance ideas.
10. Discuss: How do ideas spread in our modern world?
materials_needed: Italian vs. Northern art comparison images

slides.heading: The Renaissance Spreads
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page of our adventure! It's called "The Renaissance Spreads," and it tells us we're going to learn how all the cool new ideas that started in Italy, like art and thinking differently, traveled all the way up to the northern parts of Europe. Think of it as a history road trip!

items: Italian vs. Northern art comparison images
slides.setup_instructions: Print maps showing the spread of Renaissance ideas. Collect comparison images of Italian and Northern Renaissance art. Prepare printing press diagrams.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide is a list of all the cool stuff we'll need to make this lesson awesome. We've got maps to show where things traveled, pictures to compare Italian and Northern art (like looking at two different styles of drawing), a diagram of how a printing press works, blank maps for us to fill in, and our journals and pencils to write and draw our thoughts. It's like gathering your tools before building something amazing.

slides.text: The Renaissance began in Italy around 1350 but took over a century to spread north. Three forces carried ideas across Europe: (1) TRADE — merchants traveled and brought back Italian art and books. (2) DIPLOMACY — ambassadors and scholars visited Italian courts. (3) THE PRINTING PRESS — Gutenberg's invention (c. 1440) made books affordable and widespread. Before printing, a book cost as much as a house. After printing, ideas could reach millions.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step explains how those awesome Italian Renaissance ideas actually started moving north. Imagine merchants traveling with their goods, but they also brought back paintings and books, sharing what they saw. Ambassadors and scholars also visited Italy and brought ideas back with them. But the BIG game-changer was the printing press – before that, books were super expensive, but the press made them cheap and fast, spreading ideas like wildfire!

slides.text: The Northern Renaissance had a different character. Italian artists painted idealized human forms and classical themes. Northern artists like Jan van Eyck and Albrecht Durer painted with incredible REALISM: every wrinkle, every thread of fabric, every reflection in a mirror. Van Eyck perfected oil painting, which allowed richer colors and finer details than the Italian tempera and fresco techniques.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, this slide talks about how art in the north became a little different from Italy. While Italian artists liked to paint people looking super perfect and often used old Greek and Roman stories, artists in the north, like Jan van Eyck and Albrecht Durer, were all about making things look *exactly* real – showing every single detail, like wrinkles on a face or the shine on metal. Van Eyck even got really good at using oil paints, which made colors super rich and allowed for even more tiny details.

slides.text: ERASMUS of Rotterdam (1466-1536) was the greatest Northern humanist. He used humor and wit to criticize corruption in the Catholic Church and society. His book 'In Praise of Folly' satirized greedy clergy and foolish rulers. Unlike Italian humanists who studied classical beauty, Northern humanists focused on social reform and religious renewal. This laid the groundwork for the Protestant Reformation.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we meet Erasmus, a really important thinker from the north who was kind of like the "Leonardo da Vinci of the North" but with words! He used humor to point out silly things he saw in the church and among leaders. His writing was super smart and funny, and while Italian thinkers were focused on beauty, Erasmus and others in the north were more interested in making society better and reforming how people practiced their religion, which actually helped lead to big changes later on.

slides.text: Gutenberg's printing press was the most transformative technology since the invention of writing. By 1500, there were over 1,000 print shops across Europe producing millions of books. Literacy increased, ideas spread faster, and no authority could control the flow of information. The printing press made the Reformation, the Scientific Revolution, and the Enlightenment possible. It was the Internet of its age.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to be blown away by the printing press! This slide explains that Gutenberg's invention was a total revolution, changing everything about how information spread – it was basically the internet of its time. Before this, getting books was incredibly hard, but with the press, millions of books were made, more people learned to read, and ideas could travel faster than ever before, making big events like the Reformation possible.

slides.prompt: Trace the Renaissance's spread: (1) On a blank map of Europe, mark Florence as the Renaissance's origin and draw arrows showing how ideas spread to: the Netherlands, Germany, France, England, Spain. Label the approximate dates each region was influenced. (2) Compare an Italian Renaissance painting (e.g., Raphael's Madonna) with a Northern one (e.g., Van Eyck's Arnolfini Portrait). List 5 specific differences in style. (3) Journal: Gutenberg's press transformed how ideas spread. What modern technology has had a similar impact? Compare the printing press to the Internet: similarities and differences.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to become history detectives! First, grab a blank map of Europe and mark Florence as where the Renaissance started, then draw arrows showing how the ideas traveled to places like the Netherlands and Germany, adding the dates they were influenced. Next, look closely at the Italian and Northern art pictures and jot down five ways they are different. Finally, in your journal, think about how the printing press changed things and compare it to our modern internet – what's similar, what's different?

slides.text: The Renaissance's spread shows how ideas, once born, cannot be contained. Trade, travel, and technology carry them across borders. The printing press amplified human thought just as the Internet does today. Understanding how ideas spread helps us understand both the past and our rapidly changing present.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student trace the spread of Renaissance ideas across Europe, compare Italian and Northern Renaissance art, explain the printing press's impact, and draw parallels to modern information technology?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is a cool summary, reminding us that once ideas get going, they're hard to stop, kind of like a snowball rolling down a hill. Trade, travel, and new inventions like the printing press helped spread Renaissance ideas all over Europe, just like how technology today helps us share information instantly. It shows us that understanding how ideas spread helps us make sense of both history and our super fast-paced world.

parent_notes: The printing press is a perfect bridge to discussing modern technology. Both the press and the Internet democratized information, disrupted established authorities, and accelerated the pace of change. Ask your child: 'If Gutenberg's press was the Internet of the 1400s, what might be the next transformative technology?' The comparison between Italian and Northern Renaissance art is also rich: show your child images and let them discover the differences themselves.

title: Biodiversity and Classification — Organizing the Living World
description: Students explore Earth's biodiversity and learn how scientists classify living things using taxonomy. They practice using dichotomous keys, understand the six-kingdom classification system, and discuss why biodiversity matters for ecosystem health.
instructions:
1. Define biodiversity: the variety of life on Earth (estimated 8.7 million species).
2. Discuss why classification is necessary: organizing millions of species.
3. Introduce Carolus Linnaeus and the binomial naming system.
4. Explain the hierarchy: Domain, Kingdom, Phylum, Class, Order, Family, Genus, Species.
5. Introduce the six kingdoms: Bacteria, Archaea, Protista, Fungi, Plantae, Animalia.
6. Practice classifying organisms using characteristics.
7. Introduce dichotomous keys: step-by-step identification tools.
8. Practice using a dichotomous key to identify organisms.
9. Discuss threats to biodiversity: habitat loss, climate change, pollution.
10. Reflect: Why does biodiversity matter to humans?

slides.heading: Biodiversity and Classification
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into the amazing world of living things! It tells us we're going to learn about "Biodiversity," which is just a fancy word for all the different kinds of plants, animals, and tiny little things on Earth, and how scientists "classify" them, or sort them into groups. Think of it like organizing your toys so you know where everything is.

slides.setup_instructions: Print classification hierarchy diagrams and six kingdoms reference charts. Prepare organism cards and dichotomous keys for hands-on practice.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is telling us what we need to have ready for our activities. We've got some charts that show how scientists group living things, some examples of "dichotomous keys" which are like mystery-solving tools for nature, and some cards with pictures of different creatures. You'll also need a notebook, pencils, and colored pencils to write and draw what we learn. You'll want to grab these with a grown-up's help before we get started.

slides.text: Scientists estimate Earth has 8.7 million species, but only about 1.5 million have been discovered and named. To organize this staggering diversity, we use TAXONOMY: the science of classification. Carolus Linnaeus (1707-1778) created the system we still use. Every species gets a two-part Latin name: Homo sapiens (humans), Canis lupus (gray wolf), Quercus alba (white oak). This binomial system gives each species a unique, universal name.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we start learning *how* scientists think about all the life on Earth. They figure there are millions and millions of different species, way more than we've even found yet! To keep track, they use something called "taxonomy," which is basically a super organized system. A really smart guy named Carolus Linnaeus came up with a cool way to give every single living thing a special two-part name, kind of like a secret code, so scientists all over the world know exactly which creature you're talking about.

slides.text: The classification hierarchy from broadest to most specific: DOMAIN (3: Bacteria, Archaea, Eukarya) > KINGDOM (6) > PHYLUM > CLASS > ORDER > FAMILY > GENUS > SPECIES. Memory aid: 'Dear King Philip Came Over For Good Spaghetti.' Humans are: Eukarya > Animalia > Chordata > Mammalia > Primates > Hominidae > Homo > sapiens. Each level groups organisms by shared characteristics.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to look at the actual "family tree" of life, called the classification hierarchy. It starts super broad with "Domains," then gets more specific with "Kingdoms," and keeps going down to "Species," which is the most specific group, like just dogs or just cats. There's even a fun saying to help remember the order: 'Dear King Philip Came Over For Good Spaghetti.' It shows how everything is related, from the biggest categories down to the tiniest groups.

slides.text: The six kingdoms: BACTERIA and ARCHAEA are single-celled without a nucleus (prokaryotes). PROTISTA includes diverse single-celled eukaryotes (amoeba, algae). FUNGI include mushrooms, yeasts, and molds (they decompose organic matter). PLANTAE produce food through photosynthesis. ANIMALIA consume other organisms for energy. Each kingdom represents a fundamentally different strategy for life.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide introduces the six main "Kingdoms" where scientists put all living things. There are the super simple ones like Bacteria and Archaea, then Protista which are a bit more complex, Fungi like mushrooms, plants that make their own food, and animals like us that eat other things. Each kingdom is like a different major team, with its own way of living and surviving.

slides.text: A DICHOTOMOUS KEY is a tool for identifying organisms through a series of yes/no questions. 'Does it have a backbone? YES — go to question 2. NO — go to question 5.' Each question narrows the possibilities until you reach an identification. Dichotomous keys teach logical, step-by-step thinking — the same skill used in computer programming and medical diagnosis.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, a "dichotomous key" is like a detective's checklist for figuring out what kind of plant or animal you're looking at. It asks you a series of simple "yes" or "no" questions, and each answer helps you narrow down the possibilities until you get to the final answer. It’s a super logical way to solve puzzles, and you'll use this skill for lots of things, not just science!

slides.prompt: Classification practice: (1) Using the hierarchy diagram, classify three organisms from kingdom to species (e.g., dog, sunflower, mushroom). List each level. (2) Sort 12 organism cards into the six kingdoms based on their characteristics. (3) Use the dichotomous key to identify 5 unknown organisms. Record your path through the key for each. (4) Create your own simple dichotomous key for 8 objects in the classroom (pens, books, markers, etc.). (5) Journal: Why does biodiversity matter? Write about how losing species affects ecosystems and humans.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to put what we've learned into action! You'll use the charts to figure out the classification for some different living things, sort a bunch of creature cards into their correct kingdoms, and then use a dichotomous key to identify some mystery organisms. After that, you'll even get to make your *own* simple key for things around the classroom, and finally, you'll write in your journal about why having so many different kinds of life is so important for our planet.

slides.text: Classification gives us a framework for understanding life's incredible diversity. From bacteria to blue whales, all life on Earth is connected through evolution and organized by shared characteristics. Biodiversity is not just a scientific concept — it is the foundation of healthy ecosystems that provide us with food, medicine, clean air, and clean water. Protecting biodiversity protects our own future.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain the classification hierarchy, identify the six kingdoms and their characteristics, use a dichotomous key to identify organisms, and articulate why biodiversity matters?
slides.mascot_explanation: We've just finished a huge journey through how scientists organize all the life on Earth! You learned how to group living things from the biggest categories all the way down to specific species, and how to use those cool dichotomous keys to identify them. Remember how we talked about how important biodiversity is? It's like nature's insurance policy, making sure we have clean air, water, and even medicine for the future. You totally rocked this!

parent_notes: Classification appeals to children's natural desire to organize and categorize. The dichotomous key activity is particularly engaging — it is like a detective game. Nature walks become more interesting when you try to classify organisms you find: Is it Plantae or Fungi? What phylum? The biodiversity discussion connects to environmental stewardship: every species lost is irreplaceable. Discuss local conservation efforts and how your family can help protect biodiversity.

title: Renaissance Self-Portrait — Proportion, Expression, and Identity
description: Students apply Renaissance art principles to create self-portraits using accurate facial proportions, chiaroscuro shading, and personal symbolism. They study how Renaissance artists depicted individuality and create artworks that express their own identity.
instructions:
1. Discuss the rise of portraiture in the Renaissance: celebrating individuality.
2. Study self-portraits by Durer and Leonardo: techniques and expression.
3. Review facial proportion guidelines: eyes at halfway, nose at 3/4, etc.
4. Practice drawing facial proportions using guidelines on a template.
5. Demonstrate shading techniques for creating three-dimensional facial features.
6. Discuss symbolism in Renaissance portraits: objects that represent the subject.
7. Students plan their self-portraits: pose, expression, symbolic elements.
8. Create self-portraits applying proportion, shading, and symbolism.
9. Gallery walk: appreciate each other's work.
10. Reflect: How does art express identity?
materials_needed: Charcoal or soft pencils for shading

slides.heading: Renaissance Self-Portrait
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is the title page for our project, showing we're going to create Renaissance-style self-portraits. It tells us we'll be focusing on making our faces look realistic with correct proportions, adding cool shading to make them look 3D, and using symbols to show who we are. Think of it like designing your own superhero, but instead of powers, you're showing off what makes you, YOU!

items: Charcoal or soft pencils for shading
slides.setup_instructions: Set up mirrors at each workspace. Print facial proportion guides and self-portrait examples from various artists. Provide a range of pencil hardness for detailed shading work.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is like our artist's toolkit for this project. We've got examples of famous self-portraits to get ideas, a guide to help us draw faces correctly, mirrors so we can see our own faces, paper and pencils for drawing, special soft pencils or charcoal for shading to make things look round and real, and colored pencils if we want to add some color. Make sure you have all these things ready to go!

slides.text: Before the Renaissance, individual portraits were rare — most art depicted religious scenes. Renaissance artists celebrated INDIVIDUALITY: Albrecht Durer painted himself at age 28 looking directly at the viewer, wearing fine clothes, hair carefully arranged. This was revolutionary — an artist declaring his own importance. Self-portraits became a way to explore identity, skill, and the human condition.
slides.mascot_explanation: Back in the olden days, most paintings were about religious stuff, not regular people. But during the Renaissance, artists started thinking, "Hey, people are pretty cool too!" Artists like Durer painted themselves like they were super important, showing off their style and skills. This was a big deal because it meant art was becoming a way for people to show off their own unique selves and explore who they really were.

slides.text: Facial proportions: The eyes are approximately HALFWAY down the head (a common mistake is placing them too high). The nose ends about 3/4 down. The mouth is about 1/3 of the way between nose and chin. The space between the eyes equals one eye-width. The ears align with the eyebrows at the top and the nose at the bottom. These guidelines create realistic faces.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is super important for making your drawing look like a real face, not a cartoon! It's like a secret map for your face: your eyes sit right in the middle of your head, your nose goes about three-quarters of the way down, and your mouth is closer to your nose than your chin. And guess what? The space between your eyes is usually about the same width as one eye. Using these guides will make your face look super realistic.

slides.text: Shading brings a flat drawing to life. Decide your LIGHT SOURCE (which side is the light coming from?). The side facing the light is bright. The opposite side has shadow. The transition between light and shadow creates the illusion of a three-dimensional face. Use the side of your pencil for soft shadows and the tip for details. Blend gradually — avoid harsh lines between light and dark areas.
slides.mascot_explanation: Shading is what makes a flat drawing look like it has real shape and depth, like a real head instead of just a drawing of one. You need to figure out where your light is coming from, and then make the side facing the light brighter and the other side darker, creating shadows. It's like magic that makes your drawing pop out!

slides.text: Renaissance portraits often included SYMBOLS: a book represented learning, a globe represented worldly knowledge, flowers represented beauty or mortality. Include symbolic elements in your self-portrait that represent YOU: a musical instrument if you play music, a book if you love reading, a sports item, a pet, or anything meaningful to your identity. Your portrait should say 'This is who I am.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Renaissance artists loved putting hidden messages in their paintings, called symbols. If someone was holding a book, it meant they were smart, and flowers might mean life is beautiful but short. For your portrait, think about what things represent *you* – maybe a soccer ball if you love sports, or a favorite book if you're a big reader. These symbols tell your story without you having to say a word.

slides.prompt: Create your self-portrait: (1) Using the mirror and proportion guide, lightly sketch the basic oval of your head and mark the guidelines for eye, nose, and mouth placement. (2) Add features following the proportions: eyes, eyebrows, nose, mouth, ears, hairline. (3) Determine your light source and add shading to create depth and dimension. (4) Include at least 2 symbolic elements that represent your interests, values, or identity. (5) Add a background if time permits. (6) Gallery walk: place portraits on display and appreciate each other's work. Notice how each person's unique perspective and identity comes through in their art.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to make your masterpiece! First, use your mirror and the proportion guide to lightly sketch your head shape and mark where your eyes, nose, and mouth will go. Then, draw those features carefully, making sure they fit the proportions we learned. Next, imagine a light source and use shading to make your face look round and real. Don't forget to add at least two symbols that tell us something special about you, and if you have time, add a cool background. After you're done, we'll put them all up so we can see everyone's amazing work!

slides.text: Your self-portrait is more than a drawing — it is a statement of identity. Renaissance artists proved that every individual is worth studying and depicting. The techniques you used today — proportion, shading, and symbolism — are the same ones masters used 500 years ago. Art is one of the most powerful ways humans express who they are and what they value.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student apply facial proportion guidelines, use chiaroscuro shading to create three-dimensional form, incorporate meaningful symbolism, and reflect on how art expresses identity?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at what you've created! You took the same skills Renaissance artists used hundreds of years ago – like getting the proportions right, using shading to make things look 3D, and adding symbols to tell a story – and used them to make a portrait that shows who *you* are. It’s pretty awesome that art is such a powerful way to share your unique identity with the world.

parent_notes: Self-portraits are deeply personal and can make some children self-conscious. Emphasize that the goal is applying artistic techniques, not creating a 'perfect' likeness. Every artist's self-portrait is unique. The symbolism component adds a layer of self-reflection that is valuable beyond art class. Display the finished portrait proudly at home. If your child enjoyed this, explore self-portraits across history: Rembrandt painted over 80 self-portraits, Frida Kahlo's are intensely personal, and even modern phone selfies are a continuation of this tradition.
